expanded_description: Efficiency measures how well a machine converts input energy into useful output work. It quantifies the inevitable energy losses to friction, heat, and other dissipative processes. Understanding efficiency is crucial for designing, operating, and improving machines—from simple hand tools to complex industrial systems.

core_concept.principle: Efficiency is the ratio of useful energy output to total energy input: $\eta = \frac{E_{\text{out}}}{E_{\text{in}}} = \frac{W_{\text{out}}}{W_{\text{in}}}$ (often expressed as percentage). For machines, can also express as power ratio: $\eta = \frac{P_{\text{out}}}{P_{\text{in}}}$. Efficiency always less than or equal to 100% (η ≤ 1) due to energy conservation and inevitable losses. Difference between input and output is wasted energy: $E_{\text{wasted}} = E_{\text{in}} - E_{\text{out}} = E_{\text{in}}(1 - \eta)$, typically becoming heat via friction.
core_concept.explanation: No real machine is 100% efficient. Some input energy always converts to unusable forms—primarily heat from friction, but also sound, vibration, deformation, and other losses. Efficiency tells us what fraction of input energy becomes useful output. High efficiency (approaching 100%): Most input becomes output, little waste. Machine performs close to ideal. Examples: Electric motors (~90-95%), LED lights (~40-50%), bicycles (~95-98%). Low efficiency (far below 100%): Much input wasted, little becomes output. Machine far from ideal performance. Examples: Incandescent bulbs (~5%), gasoline engines (~25-30%), human muscles (~20-25%). Why efficiency matters: Economic: Higher efficiency → less energy input needed for same output → lower operating costs (fuel, electricity). Environmental: Less wasted energy → less fuel consumed → less pollution, resource depletion. Performance: Higher efficiency → less heat generation → cooler operation, less cooling needed, higher reliability. Theoretical limits: Some machines limited by fundamental physics (thermodynamics): Heat engines (gasoline/diesel engines, power plants) cannot exceed Carnot efficiency determined by temperature difference—typically <60% theoretical maximum, ~30-40% practical. Other machines (electric motors, mechanical devices) limited mainly by friction, resistive losses—can approach ~95-98% with good design. Understanding efficiency enables: Comparing machines objectively (which wastes less energy?). Identifying improvement opportunities (where is energy being lost?). Calculating true operating costs (accounting for waste). Designing better systems (minimize loss mechanisms). The relationship between efficiency and mechanical advantage: For simple machines: $\eta = \frac{AMA}{IMA}$ (actual MA / ideal MA). Efficiency shows how much friction reduces force multiplication below ideal prediction.

image.caption: Efficiency: $\eta = E_{\text{out}}/E_{\text{in}}$. Input energy splits: useful output + wasted energy (heat). Always η < 100%.

sections.introduction: Efficiency quantifies energy conversion effectiveness—the fraction of input energy that becomes useful output rather than waste.

key_concept.definition: Efficiency $\eta$ is the ratio of useful energy output to total energy input: $\eta = \frac{E_{\text{out}}}{E_{\text{in}}} = \frac{W_{\text{useful}}}{W_{\text{input}}}$. Can also express as power ratio: $\eta = \frac{P_{\text{out}}}{P_{\text{in}}}$ (since power = energy/time, ratios identical). Often written as percentage: multiply by 100%. For example, η = 0.75 = 75% efficient. For simple machines: $\eta = \frac{AMA}{IMA}$ relates efficiency to mechanical advantage.
key_concept.context: Efficiency is universal measure applicable to all energy conversion devices: motors, engines, heaters, lights, machines, power plants, even biological systems (muscles, metabolism). Allows comparing very different technologies on common basis.

principles.statement: Efficiency equals useful output divided by total input: $\eta = \frac{E_{\text{out}}}{E_{\text{in}}}$ or $\eta = \frac{P_{\text{out}}}{P_{\text{in}}}$. Always: $0 \leq \eta \leq 1$ (or 0% to 100%). Perfect efficiency (η = 1 or 100%) means all input becomes output—impossible in practice. Zero efficiency (η = 0) means no useful output—complete waste (also rare—even very inefficient machines produce some output).
principles.application: Calculate efficiency from measured or specified input and output energies/powers.
principles.example: Light bulb: Input 60 W electrical power, output 3 W light (rest is heat). $\eta = 3/60 = 0.05 = 5\%$ (terrible—95% wasted as heat, only 5% becomes light). Electric motor: Input 1000 W, output 900 W mechanical work. $\eta = 900/1000 = 0.9 = 90\%$ (excellent—only 10% lost to heat in windings, friction in bearings).

principles.statement: Energy conservation requires: $E_{\text{in}} = E_{\text{out}} + E_{\text{wasted}}$. Rearranging: $E_{\text{wasted}} = E_{\text{in}} - E_{\text{out}} = E_{\text{in}}(1 - \eta)$. Wasted energy (primarily heat from friction) equals input minus output. Higher efficiency → less waste.
principles.application: Calculate wasted energy from efficiency. Identify where energy goes.
principles.example: Car engine: Input 10,000 J (from fuel combustion), efficiency 28%. Output: $E_{\text{out}} = 0.28 × 10,000 = 2800$ J (mechanical work). Wasted: $10,000 - 2800 = 7200$ J (72% lost!). Goes to: Exhaust heat (~35%), Coolant heat (~30%), Friction (~7%), Other (accessories, vibration). Only ~28% moves car.

principles.statement: For simple machines: $\eta = \frac{AMA}{IMA}$ where AMA is actual (measured) mechanical advantage, IMA is ideal (geometric) mechanical advantage. This follows from: $\eta = \frac{W_{\text{out}}}{W_{\text{in}}} = \frac{F_{\text{out}} d_{\text{out}}}{F_{\text{in}} d_{\text{in}}} = \frac{F_{\text{out}}/F_{\text{in}}}{d_{\text{in}}/d_{\text{out}}} = \frac{AMA}{IMA}$
principles.application: Calculate efficiency by comparing actual to ideal MA. Shows how friction reduces performance.
principles.example: Inclined plane: IMA = 5 (geometry—length/height). Measured: AMA = 3.5 (actual force ratio). Efficiency: $\eta = 3.5/5 = 0.7 = 70\%$. Friction costs 30% of potential mechanical advantage. If frictionless: Would achieve full MA = 5, efficiency = 100%.

principles.statement: For multi-stage process (series of machines/conversions): Overall efficiency = product of individual efficiencies: $\eta_{\text{total}} = \eta_1 × \eta_2 × \eta_3 × ...$ Efficiency compounds—multiple stages multiply losses. Even good individual efficiencies can produce poor overall efficiency.
principles.application: Calculate overall efficiency for complex systems. Recognize that many stages reduce total efficiency.
principles.example: Power plant to light bulb: Power plant (coal → electricity): η₁ = 40%. Transmission lines: η₂ = 92% (8% loss). LED bulb (electricity → light): η₃ = 45%. Overall: $\eta_{\text{total}} = 0.40 × 0.92 × 0.45 = 0.166 = 16.6\%$. Only ~17% of coal's energy becomes light! Rest lost at each stage. This is why: Efficiency at every stage matters. Improving any stage improves overall. Multiple conversions should be avoided if possible (fewer stages = less cumulative loss).

principles.statement: High efficiency doesn't mean high power—they're independent: Efficiency: Fraction of input that becomes output (quality of conversion). Power: Rate of energy conversion (speed/magnitude of conversion). Can have: High efficiency, low power: Bicycle (~98% efficient, ~100-200 W human power). Low efficiency, high power: Rocket engine (~50% efficient, megawatts of power). Design goals differ: Consumer devices: High efficiency (save energy, reduce heat). Industrial/transport: Balance efficiency and power (need both performance and economy).
principles.application: Don't confuse efficiency with power. Both matter but mean different things.
principles.example: Two motors for task requiring 500 W output: Motor A: 90% efficient → needs 500/0.9 = 556 W input → wastes 56 W as heat. Motor B: 70% efficient → needs 500/0.7 = 714 W input → wastes 214 W as heat. Both deliver same 500 W output (same power). Motor A better (higher efficiency, less waste, lower energy cost, less cooling needed). But if Motor B available and affordable, can still do job—just wastes more energy.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Efficiency from Energy
worked_examples.problem: A pulley system requires 1200 J of input work to lift a load that gains 900 J of gravitational potential energy. Find the efficiency.

step_by_step.explanation: Input work: $W_{\text{in}} = 1200$ J (what you do pulling rope). Useful output: $W_{\text{out}} = 900$ J (load's PE gain).
$W_{\text{wasted}} = W_{\text{in}} - W_{\text{out}} = 1200 - 900 = 300$ J. Lost to friction in pulleys, rope bending, etc. Becomes heat.
Pulley system is 75% efficient—good but not perfect. 25% of your work (300 J) doesn't lift load, instead overcomes friction and warms components slightly.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Efficiency = useful output / total input. Difference is wasted energy (friction → heat).

worked_examples.title: Calculating Efficiency from Power
worked_examples.problem: An electric motor draws 2500 W and delivers 2200 W of mechanical power. Find: (a) efficiency, (b) power wasted as heat.

step_by_step.explanation: Motor is 88% efficient (very good for electric motors). Continuous 300 W heat output from losses (resistive heating in windings, friction in bearings). Requires cooling—fan or heat sink to dissipate this 300 W without overheating motor.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Efficiency from power ratio (same as energy ratio since both involve same time interval). Waste power must be dissipated as heat.

worked_examples.title: Finding Required Input from Efficiency
worked_examples.problem: A machine with 65% efficiency must deliver 1500 J of useful work. How much input energy is required?

step_by_step.explanation: $E_{\text{wasted}} = 2308 - 1500 = 808$ J (35% of input). Friction converts this 808 J to heat.
Need ~2308 J input to get 1500 J output. Extra 808 J (35%) lost to friction. Lower efficiency → more input needed for same output → higher energy costs.

worked_examples.concept_applied: From desired output and efficiency, find required input: $E_{\text{in}} = E_{\text{out}}/\eta$. Lower efficiency requires more input for same output.

worked_examples.title: Compound Efficiency
worked_examples.problem: A system has three stages: (1) Engine: 30% efficient, (2) Transmission: 85% efficient, (3) Final drive: 90% efficient. What is overall efficiency from fuel to wheels?

step_by_step.explanation: Start with 100 J fuel: After engine (30%): 30 J mechanical, 70 J heat/exhaust. After transmission (85% of 30): 25.5 J to drive, 4.5 J friction heat. After final drive (90% of 25.5): 23 J to wheels, 2.5 J friction heat. Result: 23 J useful (wheels), 77 J wasted (various heat). Overall: 23% efficient.

Even though transmission (85%) and final drive (90%) individually efficient, multiple stages compound losses. Overall efficiency much lower than any individual stage. This is why: Minimizing conversion stages important. Each stage takes its 'cut' of remaining energy.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Multiple stages: multiply efficiencies. Losses compound—overall efficiency lower than any individual stage. Each conversion costs energy.

worked_examples.title: Efficiency from Mechanical Advantage
worked_examples.problem: A lever has IMA = 8 (from arm lengths measured as 1.6 m and 0.2 m). In use, 25 N effort lifts 175 N load. Find efficiency.

step_by_step.explanation: Geometry predicts MA = 8. Friction reduces actual MA to 7 (12.5% loss). Efficiency 87.5%—quite good for simple lever. Losses from friction at pivot, slight bending of lever bar. Could improve with better pivot bearing (roller/ball bearing instead of simple pin), lubrication, stiffer lever material (less flex).

worked_examples.concept_applied: For simple machines: Efficiency = AMA/IMA. Friction reduces actual MA below ideal, revealing efficiency. Gap between AMA and IMA shows losses.

image.alt: Diagrams showing efficiency calculation from energy in/out and from AMA/IMA, with waste energy illustrated
image.caption: Efficiency: $\eta = E_{\text{out}}/E_{\text{in}} = P_{\text{out}}/P_{\text{in}} = AMA/IMA$. Waste = input - output. Always η < 100%.

sections.section_title: Sources of Energy Loss and Inefficiency
sections.introduction: Understanding where and why energy is lost helps identify opportunities to improve efficiency.

categories.description: Friction is the dominant energy loss mechanism in most mechanical systems.

examples.explanation: Surfaces sliding against each other: Microscopic irregularities interlock, resist motion. Kinetic friction force opposes motion: $f_k = \mu_k F_N$. Work against friction: $W_f = f_k \cdot d$ (all becomes heat). Examples: Piston sliding in cylinder (engine), Drawer sliding on rails, Block on ramp. Magnitude: Depends on friction coefficient μ and normal force. Rough surfaces, high normal force → large losses. Reduction: Lubrication (oil/grease reduces μ by factor of 5-10), Smoother surfaces (polishing reduces μ), Rollers instead of sliding (replace sliding with rolling friction—much lower).

Wheels rolling on surfaces: Much lower than sliding friction (~100× less typical), but still present. Causes: Deformation of wheel and surface at contact, Internal friction in materials (hysteresis). Examples: Car tires on road, Ball bearings, Train wheels on rails. Reduction: Harder materials (less deformation), Proper inflation (tires—optimal pressure minimizes rolling resistance), Good bearings (minimize friction in axles).

Rotating shafts in supports (bearings): Plain bearings (sleeve bearings): Shaft slides against bearing surface. Significant friction. Requires lubrication. Ball/roller bearings: Replace sliding with rolling contact. Much lower friction (~10-20× reduction). Used in: Motors, engines, wheels, machinery. Examples: Engine crankshaft rotates in bearings (oil film prevents metal-on-metal contact). Without oil: Would seize immediately (enormous friction, welding). With oil: Low friction, smooth rotation, ~90-95% bearing efficiency.

Objects moving through air: Air molecules collide with surface, creating drag force opposite to motion. Energy lost to: Turbulence (swirling air—kinetic energy in air motion), Heat (from compression, friction with surface). Increases with: Speed (drag ∝ $v^2$ typically), Surface area (larger object → more drag), Shape (blunt → high drag, streamlined → low drag). Significant for: High-speed vehicles (major power drain at highway speeds), Aircraft (most engine power overcomes drag at cruise), Fans, turbines. Reduction: Streamlining (reduce drag coefficient), Minimize frontal area, Smooth surfaces.

categories.description: Heat transfer and temperature differences cause unavoidable energy losses.

examples.explanation: Engines converting heat to work (gasoline, diesel, steam turbines, power plants): Cannot be 100% efficient—forbidden by second law of thermodynamics. Maximum possible efficiency (Carnot): $\eta_{\text{max}} = 1 - \frac{T_{\text{cold}}}{T_{\text{hot}}}$ where temperatures in Kelvin. Must reject heat to cold reservoir. Example: Car engine—combustion ~2000 K, exhaust/coolant ~400 K. Carnot maximum: $1 - 400/2000 = 80\%$ theoretical. Actual: ~25-30% (losses to friction, incomplete combustion, heat transfer, timing, etc.). Power plant: Steam 800 K, cooling water 300 K. Carnot max: ~62%. Actual: ~35-40%. Impossible to avoid: Must waste substantial heat to operate. Improvement limited by temperatures achievable (materials limits, safety, cost).

Electrical resistance in wires, components: Current through resistance generates heat: $P = I^2 R$ (power dissipated). Unavoidable in conductors (all have some resistance except superconductors at extreme cold). Examples: Electric motor windings (copper wire has resistance → heat). Transmission lines (lose ~8% of power as heat over long distances). Circuits (components warm during operation). Reduction: Thicker wires (lower resistance for same length), Better conductors (copper better than aluminum, silver best but expensive), Minimize current (for same power, higher voltage → lower current → lower $I^2R$ losses), Cooling (remove heat to prevent damage, doesn't reduce loss but manages consequences).

Heat transfer from hot to cold regions: Devices operating at temperature difference lose energy to surroundings. Examples: Refrigerator: Must remove heat leaking into cold interior (insulation reduces but doesn't eliminate). More leakage → more work needed to maintain temperature. Building heating: Heat escapes through walls, windows, roof. Must continuously supply energy to compensate. Better insulation reduces heat loss → less energy needed. Engines: Heat escapes through cylinder walls, reducing energy available for work. Insulation, thermal barriers help but can't eliminate (need to remove heat to prevent overheating).

Bending, flexing, compressing materials: Energy absorbed in deformation, some doesn't return when released (inelastic deformation). Hysteresis: Energy lost in cyclic loading/unloading (area inside stress-strain loop). Examples: Tire flex: Rubber deforms where it contacts road, relaxes leaving contact. Energy lost as heat in rubber (~10-15% of rolling resistance). Springs: Real springs heat slightly during repeated compression/extension (internal friction). Belts, chains: Flex as they go around pulleys/sprockets. Energy lost to material hysteresis. Reduction: Stiffer materials (less flex per load), Proper design (minimize unnecessary deformation), Low-hysteresis materials (some rubbers, composites engineered for low energy loss).

Vibrating components radiate sound (energy): Moving parts create oscillations, pressure waves carry energy away. Usually small loss but measurable. Examples: Engine noise (vibrations from combustion, moving parts → sound waves). Gears meshing (impacts create noise). Machinery operation (motors hum, tools buzz). Indicates: Inefficiency (ideal silent machine—all energy into useful work). Potential problems (excessive noise often signals wear, misalignment, imbalance). Reduction: Damping (absorb vibrations before becoming sound), Isolation (prevent vibration transmission), Balancing (eliminate sources of vibration), Lubrication (reduces impact forces).

Fluid systems (hydraulics, pneumatics, steam): Seals aren't perfect—small leaks allow fluid/gas to escape. Pressure losses through valves, fittings, restrictions. Examples: Hydraulic systems: Leaks past piston seals reduce effective force. Compressed air: Leaks in lines waste compressor energy (significant in older industrial systems—can lose 20-30% through leaks). Steam engines/turbines: Steam leaks around valves, seals reduce efficiency. Reduction: Better seals (tighter tolerances, better materials), Regular maintenance (replace worn seals), Proper design (minimize joints, connections where leaks occur).

image.alt: Diagram showing various loss mechanisms: friction→heat, resistance→heat, deformation→heat, sound, etc.
image.caption: Energy losses: Friction (sliding, rolling, bearings), Air resistance, Resistive heating, Deformation, Sound, Leakage. Most → heat.

sections.introduction: Different devices and systems have characteristic efficiency ranges. Understanding these helps set expectations and identify improvement opportunities.

classifications.behavior: Most input becomes output. Little waste heat.

examples.explanation: Efficiency: 85-98% depending on size, quality, load. Losses: Resistive heating in windings (~3-7%), Friction in bearings (~1-3%), Magnetic losses (eddy currents, hysteresis ~2-5%). Why so efficient: Minimal moving parts, Direct energy conversion (electrical → magnetic → mechanical), Good bearings reduce friction, Copper conductors have low resistance. Modern high-efficiency motors: 95-98% (industrial). Benefit: Cool operation (little heat), low energy cost, high performance.

Efficiency: 95-99% (large power transformers). Losses: Resistive heating in coils (~1-2%), Magnetic core losses (~1-3%). Why so efficient: No moving parts (purely electromagnetic), Simple design (minimal complexity), Good materials (low-resistance copper, low-loss magnetic cores). Critical for power grid: Transformers step voltage up/down many times between power plant and home. Must be highly efficient (even 2% loss × many transformations = significant waste). Typical grid: ~8% total loss including transformers and transmission lines.

Efficiency: 95-98% (chain drive). Losses: Chain friction (~1-2%), Bearing friction (~0.5-1%), Tire rolling resistance (~1-2%). Why so efficient: Simple mechanics (few friction points), Ball bearings (replace sliding with rolling), Lubrication easy (chain oil dramatically reduces friction), Light load (human power scale). Result: Nearly all pedaling power reaches wheel. Extremely efficient transportation (100+ MPGe equivalent—miles per gallon equivalent if human powered by food).

classifications.behavior: Most input useful, but noticeable losses to heat.

examples.explanation: Efficiency: 75-85% typical. Losses: Friction in cylinders, valves (~10-15%), Leakage past seals (~5-10%), Fluid turbulence, pressure drops. Why moderately efficient: Fluid friction substantial (viscosity), Many seals, joints (leak paths), High pressures increase leakage. Advantage: Very high force capability (pressure × area). Used where: High force needed (construction equipment, presses), Precise control required (aircraft, manufacturing), Smooth operation desired. Trade-off: Accept ~20% loss for high force and control.

Efficiency per gear mesh: ~97-99% (well-made gears). Multi-stage transmission: ~80-95% overall (losses compound). Losses: Gear tooth sliding friction, Bearing friction, Oil churning (power absorbed moving lubricant). Why fairly efficient: Rolling/sliding at tooth contact (not pure sliding), Good lubrication (oil reduces friction), Precision manufacturing (smooth operation). Examples: Manual transmission: ~94-96% (direct mechanical connection, few gears). Automatic transmission: ~80-88% (more gears, hydraulic coupling, pumps). Reduction gear box (4 stages): ~0.98⁴ ≈ 92% (compounding).

classifications.value: Significant losses, but acceptable for applications
classifications.behavior: Roughly half input becomes output. Major heat generation.

examples.explanation: Efficiency: 35-45% (best designs). Losses: Exhaust heat (~30-35%), Coolant heat (~25-30%), Friction (~5-10%), Other (alternator, pumps, accessories). Why better than gasoline: Higher compression ratio (more complete combustion, higher temperature differential), Leaner burn (excess air improves efficiency), Direct injection (precise fuel delivery). Still limited: Thermodynamic constraints (Carnot limit ~55-60% for temperatures achieved). Friction, pumping losses. Result: Best practical heat engines for vehicles. Trucks, ships, trains use diesel. Improving: Turbocharging (recovers exhaust energy), Advanced controls, Better materials (allow higher temperatures → better thermodynamic efficiency).

Efficiency: Coal: ~33-40%, Natural gas: ~40-60% (combined cycle), Nuclear: ~33-37%. Losses: Condenser (must reject heat to maintain temperature difference) ~45-55%, Exhaust, radiation ~5-10%, Auxiliary systems (pumps, etc.) ~2-5%. Why limited: Carnot efficiency constraint (temperature limits from materials, safety), Need to reject heat for thermodynamic cycle (can't convert all to work). Best technology (combined cycle gas turbine): ~60% efficiency. Uses exhaust heat from gas turbine to power steam turbine (two cycles in series, reduces waste). Result: Most electricity generated with ~60-65% loss to heat. Improvement difficult (fundamental physics limits).

Efficiency: 20-25% mechanical work from chemical energy. Losses: Heat from metabolism (~75-80% of food energy → heat). Why low: Biochemical processes inefficient (many intermediate steps, each loses energy), Muscle contraction mechanism has inherent losses, Maintaining body temperature requires heat (some 'waste' is useful for warmth). Comparable to: Car engines (~25-30%)—similar efficiency range! Evolution optimized for: Versatility (many movement types), Control (precision), Endurance (sustainable over hours), Not maximum efficiency. Result: Humans are 'warm-blooded' largely because muscles waste 75-80% of energy as heat. In cold weather, advantage. In heat, must cool (sweating).

classifications.behavior: Minority of input becomes output. Extreme heat generation.

examples.explanation: Efficiency: 25-30% typical (modern cars). Losses: Exhaust heat (~35-40%), Coolant heat (~30-35%), Friction, pumping (~10-15%), Accessories. Why worse than diesel: Lower compression ratio (knock prevention), Richer fuel mixture (cooling, power), Less optimal combustion. Thermodynamic limit: ~50-55% Carnot (lower combustion temperature than diesel). Practical: ~25-30% (half of theoretical maximum). Improvements: Direct injection, variable valve timing, turbocharging, cylinder deactivation. Pushing toward ~35% in best engines. Result: 70-75% of fuel energy wasted as heat. Why cars have: Large radiators (must dissipate coolant heat), Exhaust systems (vent hot gases), Poor fuel economy (only ~25% of gas moves car).

Efficiency: ~5% light, 95% heat. Why terrible: Visible light requires specific wavelengths (400-700 nm, violet to red). Hot filament radiates all wavelengths (blackbody radiation). Most energy in infrared (heat), not visible light. Only small fraction in visible spectrum. Result: Mostly space heater, incidentally produces light. Replacement: LED (~40-50% efficient—10× better), Fluorescent (~20-30%—4-6× better). Both produce light directly (not via heat), less waste. Incandescent banned/phased out in many countries due to horrible efficiency.

Screw jack: Efficiency ~30-50% (fine threads, high friction). Wedge: Efficiency ~50-80% (depends on angle, lubrication). Incline with friction: Efficiency ~50-70% (depends on slope, surface). Why low: Friction proportional to normal force (high for these applications). Sliding contact throughout motion (continuous friction work). Often unlubricated or poorly lubricated (tools, temporary setups). Trade-off: Accept low efficiency for: High mechanical advantage (screw: MA ~ 100-1000), Self-locking (screw stays in place—friction is feature, not bug for holding load), Simplicity (no complex parts, cheap, durable). When efficiency matters: Use alternatives (hydraulic jack ~75-85%, electric motor + gears ~90%+).

image.caption: Efficiency comparison: Electric motors (>90%), Diesel engines (~40%), Gasoline engines (~28%), LED (~45%), Incandescent (~5%)

sections.introduction: Understanding efficiency enables targeted improvements and informed decisions about energy use and system design.

examples.explanation: Single most effective improvement for mechanical systems: Reduces friction coefficient by factor of 5-20× (dry vs lubricated). Small investment, huge efficiency gain. Types: Oil (fluid lubrication—separates surfaces with liquid film), Grease (thick oil with additives—stays in place), Solid lubricants (graphite, PTFE for extreme conditions). Examples: Engine oil: Without: μ ~1.0 (metal-on-metal), seizes in seconds. With: μ ~0.05, smooth operation, ~90% efficiency. Bicycle chain: Without: ~80% efficient, wears quickly. With: ~98% efficient, lasts years. Maintenance: Regular lubrication critical. Old/degraded oil loses effectiveness. Change oil per manufacturer schedule maintains efficiency.

Replace sliding friction with rolling friction: Plain bearing (sleeve): Shaft slides against bearing surface. High friction. Ball/roller bearings: Balls/rollers roll between races. ~10-20× lower friction. Applications: Motors, wheels, machinery—anywhere shafts rotate. Impact: Motor with ball bearings: ~95% efficient. Same motor with plain bearings: ~80% efficient. 15% gain just from bearing choice. Cost: Ball bearings more expensive initially, but pay back through energy savings and longer life (less wear).

Streamlining reduces air resistance (major loss at high speeds): Drag coefficient (Cd): Dimensionless number characterizing shape. Lower = less drag. Flat plate perpendicular to airflow: Cd ~1.3 (terrible). Sphere: Cd ~0.5. Streamlined teardrop: Cd ~0.05 (excellent, 25× better than plate). Impact on vehicles: Semi truck: Cd ~0.6-0.8 (blunt, boxy). With aerodynamic fairing: Cd ~0.5 (15-30% reduction) → 15-30% fuel savings at highway speeds! Sports car: Cd ~0.25-0.35 (designed for efficiency and appearance). Trade-offs: Aerodynamic shape vs interior space, manufacturing cost, styling preferences. Example: Fuel savings from aerodynamic improvements can be 10-30% at highway speeds (where air resistance dominates energy use).

Better materials reduce losses: Low-friction coatings: PTFE (Teflon), diamond-like carbon (DLC) on surfaces. Reduce μ to 0.05-0.15 (vs ~0.3-0.8 uncoated). Low-loss magnetics: Special steel alloys, ferrites for motors/transformers. Reduce magnetic hysteresis losses. High-temperature materials: Ceramics, superalloys allow higher engine temperatures → better thermodynamic efficiency (closer to Carnot limit). Lightweight materials: Aluminum, composites, carbon fiber reduce mass → less energy to accelerate, less rolling resistance. Examples: Ceramic bearings: 20-30% lower friction than steel, last longer. Carbon fiber car body: 40-50% weight reduction → 20-30% fuel economy improvement. Cost: Advanced materials expensive, but justified for high-performance applications (racing, aerospace, precision equipment).

Run devices at optimal speed for efficiency: Pumps, fans, compressors: Most efficient at design speed. Reduced efficiency at partial load or overload. Variable frequency drives (VFD): Adjust motor speed to match load (rather than running full speed with throttling). Energy savings: 20-50% in typical applications. Example: Building HVAC (heating, ventilation, air conditioning): Old system: Fans run full speed, dampers restrict flow (wastes energy). VFD system: Fans run slower when less cooling needed. Energy use proportional to need. Result: 30-50% energy savings vs constant-speed system.

categories.description: How machines are used affects efficiency

examples.explanation: Machines have efficiency sweet spot (load range): Underloaded: Fixed losses (friction, idle power) larger fraction of output. Inefficient. Overloaded: Excessive heat, stress. Efficiency drops. Risk of damage. Optimal loading: Typically 70-95% of rated capacity. Peak efficiency. Examples: Electric motors: Most efficient at 75-90% of rated power. 50% load: ~5% less efficient. 25% load: ~10-15% less efficient. Transformers: Most efficient near full load. Generators: Best efficiency at ~80-90% capacity. Design/operation: Size equipment for typical load (not peak). Multiple smaller units (run some at high efficiency) vs one large (runs at low efficiency most of time). Example: Data center cooling: Three 33%-capacity chillers (run 1-3 as needed, each near peak efficiency) vs one 100% chiller (often runs at low efficiency).

Poor maintenance dramatically reduces efficiency: Dirty filters (air, oil, fuel): Restrict flow, increase pressure drop → pumps/fans work harder → more energy for same output. Worn parts: Increased clearances → more leakage (hydraulics, engines). Loose fits → more friction, vibration. Misalignment: Shafts, pulleys not aligned → binding, uneven wear → higher friction. Low/degraded lubricant: Friction increases 5-20× → efficiency drops, wear accelerates. Impact: Well-maintained equipment: Operates at design efficiency (~90-95% for motors). Poorly maintained: Efficiency can drop 10-30% (to ~60-80%). Example: Industrial motor: Clean, aligned, lubricated: 93% efficient, draws 50 kW for 46.5 kW output. Dirty, misaligned, dry bearings: 75% efficient, draws 62 kW for same 46.5 kW output. Extra 12 kW wasted → $10,000+/year extra energy cost (at $0.10/kWh, 24/7 operation). Preventive maintenance pays for itself through energy savings alone (plus extends equipment life, prevents failures).

Capture and use waste heat instead of venting: Cogeneration (combined heat and power—CHP): Use engine exhaust heat for space heating, water heating, process heat. Example: Natural gas engine generates electricity at 35% efficiency, produces 60% waste heat. CHP captures heat → overall 90%+ system efficiency. Industrial heat recovery: Exhaust heat from furnaces, kilns → preheat combustion air, boil water for steam. Automotive: Turbochargers use exhaust heat to compress intake air (more power from same fuel). Future systems may generate electricity from exhaust heat (thermoelectric generators). Impact: Can improve overall system efficiency 20-40% by using waste heat productively. Challenges: Must have nearby use for heat (limits applications). Capital cost of heat exchangers, piping.

Higher efficiency = lower energy bills: Payback calculation: Compare high-efficiency (higher cost) vs standard (lower cost). Calculate energy savings × time → find payback period. Example: LED vs incandescent (10,000 hour life): Incandescent: 60 W, $1, uses 600 kWh → $72 electricity cost (@ $0.12/kWh). LED: 9 W (same light), $4, uses 90 kWh → $11 electricity cost. LED costs $3 more initially, saves $61 over life. Payback: $3/($72-$11) × 10,000 hr ≈ 500 hours ≈ 3 months if used 5 hr/day. After payback: Pure savings. Total lifetime savings: $61 - $3 = $58 per bulb. Industrial: High-efficiency motor $1000 vs standard $600. Difference $400. Energy savings: 5 kW × 8000 hr/yr × $0.10/kWh = $4000/yr. Payback: $400/$4000 = 0.1 year ≈ 5 weeks! Then $4000/yr savings every year. Efficiency improvements often pay for themselves quickly through reduced operating costs.

Higher efficiency → less fuel/electricity → less pollution: Power generation: ~60% of US electricity from fossil fuels. Every kWh saved → ~0.5 kg less CO₂ emissions (national average). LED saving 510 kWh (vs incandescent): ~255 kg less CO₂ over bulb life. High-efficiency vehicle (40 MPG vs 20 MPG): Same 15,000 miles/year: 40 MPG uses 375 gallons fuel vs 750 gallons. Saves 375 gallons → ~3.5 tons less CO₂/year. Resource conservation: Less fuel → slower depletion of oil, coal, gas reserves. Lower resource extraction environmental impact. Efficiency crucial for sustainability: Can't eliminate fossil fuel use overnight (technology, infrastructure constraints). But can reduce consumption 30-50% through efficiency improvements with current technology. Efficiency is 'cleanest, cheapest energy source'—every Joule not wasted is Joule that doesn't need to be generated.

Governments mandate minimum efficiency to drive improvement: Appliance standards: Minimum efficiency for refrigerators, air conditioners, water heaters, lights, etc. Gradually increased over time—drives manufacturers to improve. Vehicle fuel economy standards: CAFE (Corporate Average Fuel Economy) in US requires automakers to meet fleet average MPG. Increases over time → forces technology development. Building codes: Minimum insulation, window performance, HVAC efficiency for new construction. Energy labeling: Energy Star (US), EU energy labels show efficiency ratings. Helps consumers choose efficient products. Impact: Refrigerators: 1970s average ~1800 kWh/year. Today's average ~450 kWh/year (75% reduction!). Same service, much less energy. Cars: 1975 average ~13 MPG. 2020 average ~25 MPG (nearly double). Standards saved billions of dollars and reduced emissions substantially.

summary: Efficiency measures how well energy converts to useful output: $\eta = E_{\text{out}}/E_{\text{in}} = W_{\text{out}}/W_{\text{in}}$ or $\eta = P_{\text{out}}/P_{\text{in}}$ (energy or power ratio—same result). Expressed as decimal (0 to 1) or percentage (0% to 100%). Always η ≤ 100% in real machines (equal only if truly no losses—impossible practically). Wasted energy: $E_{\text{wasted}} = E_{\text{in}} - E_{\text{out}} = E_{\text{in}}(1 - \eta)$, typically becomes heat via friction. For simple machines: $\eta = AMA/IMA$ (actual MA / ideal MA)—shows how friction reduces force multiplication below geometric prediction. Compound efficiency: Multiple stages multiply: $\eta_{\text{total}} = \eta_1 × \eta_2 × \eta_3 × ...$. Even good individual efficiencies produce poor overall if many stages (avoid unnecessary conversions). Major loss mechanisms: (1) Friction—sliding (kinetic friction, significant losses), rolling (much lower, but still present), bearings (shaft rotation in supports), air resistance (fluid friction, drag ∝ $v^2$). (2) Thermal—heat engines limited by thermodynamic Carnot efficiency $\eta_{\text{max}} = 1 - T_{\text{cold}}/T_{\text{hot}}$ (cannot exceed ~50-60% practically), resistive heating in electrical components ($P = I^2R$), heat leakage from temperature differences. (3) Other—material deformation/hysteresis (energy absorbed in flexing), sound and vibration (energy radiated as pressure waves), leakage in fluid systems (seals imperfect). Typical efficiencies by category: Very high (>90%): Electric motors 85-98%, transformers 95-99%, bicycles 95-98%. High (70-90%): Pumps/fans 75-85%, hydraulics 75-85%, gears 80-95%. Moderate (40-70%): Diesel engines 35-45%, LEDs 40-50%, power plants 33-60%, human muscles 20-25%. Low (<40%): Gasoline engines 25-30%, incandescent bulbs ~5%, screw jacks 30-50%. Improving efficiency—technical: Lubrication (reduces friction 5-20×, most cost-effective improvement), Better bearings (ball/roller vs plain—10-20× friction reduction), Aerodynamic design (streamlining reduces drag coefficient, 15-30% savings for vehicles at high speeds), Advanced materials (low-friction coatings, high-temperature alloys, lightweight composites), Variable speed operation (VFDs match motor speed to load, 20-50% energy savings). Improving efficiency—operational: Optimal loading (run equipment at 70-95% capacity for peak efficiency), Regular maintenance (clean filters, lubricate, align—prevents 10-30% efficiency degradation), Waste heat recovery (cogeneration/CHP uses exhaust heat, improves system efficiency to 90%+). Economic impact: Higher efficiency → lower energy costs. Payback period often <1 year for industrial equipment. Lifetime savings can be 10-100× initial cost premium. Example: High-efficiency motor costs 40% more, saves 80% of cost premium in first 2 months through reduced electricity use, then saves $4000/year for 20+ year life. Environmental impact: Efficiency reduces fuel consumption → less pollution, less CO₂, slower resource depletion. Standards (appliance efficiency, vehicle MPG, building codes) drive continuous improvement—refrigerators use 75% less energy than 1970s, cars nearly double fuel economy. Policy approach: Efficiency is cheapest, cleanest 'new energy source'—every Joule not wasted doesn't need generating. Understanding efficiency critical for: Comparing energy conversion devices objectively, Identifying where improvements yield biggest benefits (target high-loss mechanisms), Calculating true operating costs (account for waste over lifetime), Designing sustainable systems (minimize environmental impact), Making informed purchasing decisions (balance initial cost vs lifetime energy cost).
